app.title: My Watershed - Central Puget Sound
app.name: My Watershed
app.meta_description: Welcome! We are here to educate and inspire action for our Central Puget Sound watersheds.

info.title: WRIA Boundaries ALL
info.body:
WRIA 9 is comprised of the Green River and Duwamish River Watersheds. It aso includes the nearshore habitat and small drainages along Elliott Bay (downtown Seattle), plus the Puget Sound shoreline along West Seattle, Burien, Normandy Park, Des Moines and Federal Way, as well as all of Vashon Island.

A natural watershed is the total land area draining into a river, lake, or Puget Sound defined by its rlayerGroupIdgelines. Water Resource Inventory Areas (WRIAs) are administrative units authorized under the Water Resources Act of 1971. These boundaries, which can include more than one watershed and many sub-basins, help resource managers, planners, and policy makers improve collaborative decision making around salmon recovery, farms, flooding, forestry, and stormwater management.

The Washington State Department of Ecology was given the responsibility for the development and management of these administrative and planning boundaries. There are 62 "Water Resource Inventory Areas" across the state.

fields.name: cover-image
fields.prompt: Insert a compelling cover image and/or project site map
fields.label: Cover image

fields.name: problem-statement
fields.placeholder: What problem are you trying to solve?

fields.name: goal
fields.placeholder: Make it clear, specific, and concise. Best to include your intended impact in the goal statement.

fields.name: location-description
fields.placeholder: Name the street or nearest intersection. Or, if your project is in a natural setting without a clear street address to reference, describe the parcel, park, stream or river mile. For example: Jasper Park off Riverview Road at river mile 17. You can also embed images or detailed site maps in this section.

fields.name: background
fields.placeholder: What's the situation? What are the challenges and opportunities?

fields.name: city-goal-alignment
fields.placeholder: Provide annotated links to policies, plans or performance measures of your city or county government. Research your citys Climate Action Plan or Master Sustainability Plan or Environmental Stewardship Plan. How does your project advance specific actions called out in one of these plans?

fields.name: stakeholders
fields.placeholder: Who cares about this issue? Who needs to care? Be specific. Make a list and describe each stakeholders point of view.

fields.name: action-steps
fields.placeholder: List what steps were taken to implement your solution. Its great to embed images or video showing before and after, or in other ways documenting the journey of actions taken.

fields.name: impact-data
fields.placeholder: Provide evidence, data, and a brief narrative explanation. We encourage you to embed a table or graph in this section. If applicable, describe the number and demographics of people directly impacted. Be sure to describe how your project directly supports one or more city goals (local policies, plans or performance measures). Feel free to insert a link to Read more about this project or  See the Full Report. You might also link to an extensive photo gallery of your project. Pictures are great!

fields.name: next-steps
fields.placeholder: What needs to happen next? What are your plans or recommendations?

attrs.value: Receive email updates on your report

content: Native Land Maps: Territories, Languages, Treaties

This resource maps Indigenous land territories to challenge the way people view their land. The map does not intend to represent legal boundaries of any Indigenous nations but strengthen the spiritual bonds that people have with their land, language, and treaties. Additional features include a teachers' guide and territory acknowledgement.

For most of its history, Seattle was a tightly segregated city, committed to white supremacy and the separation of those considered not white. The maps provided by the University of Washington show the neighborhood distribution of African American, Asian American, Native American, Latino, and White populations across nine decades. This resource also includes the location and history of racially restrictive covenants in Seattle and along the Eastside.
Washington State Treaty Ceded Areas Map

This map portrays the tribal reservations and drafted treaty ceded areas of the Indigenous peoples of Washington State. Ceded areas are off-reservation lands ceded by a tribe to the United States in exchange for protection, services, and possibly cash payments.
Federally Recognized Tribes of Washington State Map
This map displays the present-day reservations of Indigenous people recognized by the United States federal government.
Map for Tracking Toxins in Your Neighborhood

This map displays cleanup sites of the Toxics Cleanup Program within a desired range of a zip code or address in Washington State. The Toxics Cleanup Program (TCP) works to clean up contaminated properties throughout Washington State.
• YouTube - Student Examples of Neighborhood Investigations

This map allows users to find self-guided sites and virtual opportunities to observe salmon migrating to spawn at sites near King County. The TAKE ACTION button educates users on how they can help protect salmon.

This collection of maps shows the distribution of key demographics within King County: income, race/ethnicity, and languages spoken in King County. The resource creates many interesting points of inquiry surrounding the income and racial dynamics in King County.
The United States Census Bureau provides a collection of large-scale maps based on census data surrounding educational attainment, median household income, employment status, and more.
Mapping Inequality - Redlining in New Deal America

This collection of maps includes the color-coded mortgage security grades assigned to neighborhoods in Seattle and Tacoma. Between 1935 and 1940, agents of the federal government's Home Owners' Loan Corporation assigned grades to neighborhoods that reflected their supposed mortgage security. A grade of "A" was deemed minimally risky for banks whereas "D" indicated that the area was hazardous for investors. The HOLC consistently assigned lower grades to neighborhoods consisting of minorities and working class white people which led lenders to refuse to make loans in these areas.

The Food Access Research Atlas presents a spatial overview of food access indicators for low-income and other census tracts using different measures of supermarket accessibility. This map can be downloaded for community planning or research purposes.
This map displays the number and location of Built Green certified properties in the Greater Seattle Area.

This dynamic, multi-layered map features information on salmonid fish distribution, ESA status, juvenile fish monitoring, hatcheries and rearing facilities, and stream blockages. The various map views display data by watershed, county boundary, cities, and at a specified longitude and latitude. The tool also allows students to visually grasp the relationships among habitat features, human development and fish stock status within a watershed or geographic area.

The Waterlines Project Map is a rendering of the Seattle region in the mid-19th century, just prior to non-Indigenous settlement, created using photorealistic aerial views collaged with hand painting. The map content integrates research from the sciences, natural and cultural histories, and informed imaginings. The resource also features four tours of the areas history presented through the lens of its changing landscape going back 20,000 years.
Making Our Watershed Fit for a King - Poster Map

This high resolution infographic tells the story of the Green Duwamish and Central Puget Sound Watershed from the perspective of improving habitat for King Salmon which is the popular name for Chinook Salmon. Chinook, the biggest of our local salmon species, are threatened with extinction and they are the main food for Puget Sound Orca. Scroll and zoom around this beautiful poster to learn the story of Chinook Salmon and how we can save them. The infographics found around this map are also used to illustrate the Green Duwamish Habitat Plan.
• Executive Summary of the Green Duwamish Salmon Habitat Plan

This collection of map brochures of King County Parks system offers trails with year-round accessibility for hiking, mountain biking, and horseback riding. Each of the map brochures focus on a different backcountry location and its trail features and are available to download and print.

This mapping tool helps users map their next bike ride or commute route. The site includes a list of state and local bike and trails maps for Washington State. Check out additional bike maps of the Puget Sound Region below!
• Cascade Bicycle Club - Bike maps in the Puget Sound region
• City of Seattle - Bike map of Seattle

The Sound Impacts online portal maps the location of green infrastructure in Western Washington including rain gardens, permeable pavement, tree planting, green roofs, and more. Additional resources of green infrastructure projects that have been built in Seattle over the past two decades can be found in the resources below!
• Green Stormwater Infrastructure Projects Near You - Seattle
Combined Sewer Outfall Real Time Status Map

This map displays potential combined sewer overflow, or CSO, locations in the Seattle area. Users can view this map before going swimming, wading, fishing, or boating near a CSO warning sign within the City of Seattle. Click on each green dot or CSO outfall symbol to learn more.

The Walk Score interactive map ranks homes and apartments in over 2,800 cities and 10,000 neighborhoods based on their walkability. Users can click on various properties throughout the United States and Canada and view their walkability scores.
This map displays the storm drainage systems located in Kent, Washington including storm sewer lines, detention facilities, pump stations, and drainage utility basin boundaries.

This is a series of seven maps that cover the full length of the Green-Duwamish River, section by section. You can zoom in to see exactly where trees need to be planted to benefit salmon along every river mile. The maps in this series display the priority areas for tree planting due to the lack of tall native trees especially along the Green River and Soos and Newaukum Creeks. The lack of trees causes unhealthy and sometimes lethal conditions for Chinook and other salmon. This map represents one of the Re-Green the Green Revegetation strategies developed by the WRIA 9 Riparian Revegetation Work Group.
• Learn more about the initiative to Re-Green the Green

This map depicts the known freshwater distribution of chinook salmon for Water Resource Inventory Area (WRIA) 8 ore the Cedar, Lake Washington, Lake Sammamish Watershed. The depicted limits of known freshwater distribution of chinook salmon are based upon the collective personal knowledge of participants in the WRIA 8 mapping project and data they gathered from published and unpublished databases. This map may underestimate or overestimate the actual distribution of chinook salmon.
• Learn more about Chinook Salmon Conservation Plan for WRIA 8
Interactive Maps for City of Seattle
The Seattle Department of Transportation hosts more than a dozen very specific interactive map stories, from School Walking and Biking, to Parking Zones, from Urban Forestry to potholes.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics salmon watersystems pollution foodsystems greenbuilding transportationsystems'>

The City of Bellevue offers a variety of standard PDF maps, downloadable spatial data and interactive web maps that help keep residents and visitors informed. Visit the full Map Gallery or preview featured interactive web maps below to explore city projects, plans and other city initiatives.

OldMapsOnline, a search engine for historical maps, developed out of a love of history and heritage of old maps. The website has been created by Klokan Technologies GmbH, specialists in online map publishing and in applications of open-source software. It aims to demonstrate a combination of tools for publishing historical maps with a focus on their easy accessibility for the general public. ince January, 2013, the project has been improved and maintained by volunteers and the team of Klokan Technologies GmbH in their free time. Find dozens of old Seattle Maps including some really early ones from 1897.

This is a high resolution poster of an historical drawing depicting what Seattle looked like in 1891. It is drawn from an oblique, birds eye view. By clicking on the poster, you can scroll around and zoom in for a fascinating tour of Seattle and the surrounding parts of King County in 1891.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics indigenous history salmon watersystems pollution transportationsystems'>

This beautiful map from 1909 shows downtown Seattle and a few of the surrounding small communities that will later become incorporated as Seattle neighborhoods. It also features the natural estuary and broad meandering floodplain of the Duwamish Valley. This image was rendered just a few years before the construction of Harbor Island and the channelization of the Duwamish River. This choice will rapidly advance Seattles deep port Industrial development, but will destroy thousands of acres of vital Salmon habitat.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics indigenous history salmon watersystems pollution transportationsystems'>

This beautiful map from 1897 shows much of King and Snohomish County including east of Lake Sammamish. You can scroll around and zoom in on this drawing to see the street grid of old Seattle, the natural estuary and broad meandering floodplain of the Duwamish Valley and the largely undeveloped land of all the suburban communities we know today. This was only about 130 years ago. The pace of urban development in our region is pretty breathtaking and has come with both intended and unintended consequences.
People Commuting To Work By Biking in King County

Another fascinating map story from King Countys Communities Count, a dashboard with geospatial data on many different attributes and behaviors in our communities. This map, on adults who commute to work by biking, includes trends on age, race, poverty, and neighborhoods.
People Commuting To Work By Walking in King County

Another fascinating map story from King Countys Communities Count, a dashboard with geospatial data on many different attributes and behaviors in our communities. This map, on adults who commute to work by walking, includes trends on age, race, poverty, and neighborhoods.

This is not exactly a map, but we couldn't leave it out, as it is the earliest known drawing of downtown Seattle, which was little more than an outpost that included a fort, a sawmill, a church, and a house of prostituion. See if you can figure out from this drawing and other historical maps of old Seattle where the stadiums, ferry terminals, and skyscrapers would be today. Notice that right behind this cluster of little buildings looms the massive old growth forest that once blanketed every acre of land all the way up to the Cascades. A Lieutenant in the US Navy sketched this view while at anchor in Elliot Bay during the Treaty Wars of 1855-56. Why were their treaty wars?
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics indigenous history salmon watersystems pollution foodsystems greenbuilding transportationsystems'>

This is a series of seven drawings of a fictitious watershed showing the evolution of human development decisions based on the original natural resources of the watershed. The series takes us from the watershed in its natural state before human settlement, to the first native village of five longhouses near the estuary, all the way to complete urbanization, much like the development story of Seattle and King County and the local watershed that accommodated such rapid growth. The series was hand drawn by Peter Donaldson, Director of Learning for Sustainability Ambassadors. The process began with an initial watershed map, then the addition of five longhouses and a few trails for hunting and gathering, then the addition of a trading fort and sawmill, and so on. Each subsequent layer was photocopied before more detail was added. There is no legend, timeframe, or explanation of the iconography. It is a puzzle with many possible explanations for the intended and unintended consequences of human impact on the environment. Try making one of your own.

This useful collection of maps at the County level includes natural resource topics such as: average annual precipitation, 100-year and 500-year floodplains, land use, water quality in small lakes, and noxious weed distribution.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics history salmon watersystems pollution foodsystems greenbuilding transportationsystems'>
Historical Aerial Photos of Communities in King County

The image in the thumbnail is downtown Redmond in 1936. This fascinating collection includes only a few selected King County Communities, but it gives you an awesome window into the rapid development of our landscape. Check out some of the other cities.
<figure class='mwl__gallery-item' data-tags='demographics equity pollution foodsystems transportationsystems'>
What makes Georgetown and South Park Healthy and Unhealthy Maps

The Duwamish River Cleanup Coalition/Technical Advisory Group used Community Based Participatory Research in Georgetown and South Park to retrieve information about how to improve community health and eliminate health disparities. The maps communicate all health related concerns as well as features that contribute to a healthy community.
San Francisco Map of Tap Water Stations

San Francisco Public Utilities Commision has installed lead-free outdoor water bottle refilling stations ("tap stations") around the City to provide everyone with free access to high-quality tap water while on the go. This encourages conservation of natural resources and reduces waste from single-use plastic water bottles. Why cant we have a map like this in our own community?
